stem: A 52-year-old client with a urinary tract infection (UTI) becomes increasingly confused and hypotensive. Based on the documentation in the Sepsis Bundle Tracking & Perfusion Log tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition and phase, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Suspected Sepsis progression.
Background: Admitted for Pyelonephritis. History of Type 2 Diabetes.
Assessment: Skin is flushed, dry, and warm to the touch. Client is restless and disoriented.
Recommendation: Immediate Lactate level and blood culture collection.

tabs.title: Sepsis & Perfusion Log
tabs.content:
AssessmentCurrent FindingInterpretation
Cardiac OutputIncreased (Hyperdynamic)Systemic Vasodilation
Lactate Level4.8 mmol/L (High)Inadequate tissue perfusion
Urine Output18 mL in last 2 hoursOliguria
Skin StatusWarm; Flushed; PinkEarly Phase Sign

actionOptions.text: Draw blood cultures (Aerobic/Anaerobic) from two different sites
Initiate a rapid IV bolus of 30 mL/kg of Crystalloids (NS or LR)
Apply cooling blankets to treat the warm, flushed skin
Place the client in a high-Fowler's position to support breathing

parameterOptions.text: Serum Lactate and venous oxygen saturation (ScvO2)
Presence of a positive Babinski sign
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose

rationale.correct: This client is in Early (Warm) Septic Shock (c1). Key cues include: Warm/flushed skin, high fever, and hypotension despite a high cardiac output (Hyperdynamic phase). The Lactate level of 4.8 confirms shock (anaerobic metabolism). Priority actions are obtaining cultures before antibiotics (a1) and aggressive fluid resuscitation (a2) to overcome the massive vasodilation. Monitoring MAP (p1) (Goal >65) and tracking Lactate (p2) are the standards of the Surviving Sepsis Campaign.
clinicalPearls: In early sepsis, the skin is warm because of massive vasodilation; in late sepsis, the skin becomes cold/mottled as the heart fails and blood is shunted to core organs.
The '30 mL/kg' crystalloid rule is the gold standard for septic shock fluid resuscitation.

questionTrap.trap: Applying ice packs to the 'warm/flushed' skin to treat the fever.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: The flush in sepsis is caused by VASODILATION, not just the fever. Cooling will NOT fix the lack of blood pressure. Focus on FLUIDS and CULTURES.
